history.content: I am a transfer too, so maybe I can help! I also had credit for 61B and discrete math, but took 61B and 70 last year (not together though) which was a great decision because I learned so much more! So even though I took discrete math, 70 was much harder, not really because of the concepts, but just the homework assignments and exams. They take up most of the week, unless you are exceptionally smart or have a great group. Now, 61B is pretty easy and fun if you already took Data Structures/Java courses, but the projects and assignments also take up a good amount of time. So the combo of 61B and 70 shouldn't be bad conceptually, but you will just have a good amount of "work". As for 184, I haven't taken it so I'm not sure, but with these 3 techs, I would say it is doable, but it might be hard to get all A's (it is possible though), and you will have some rough weeks. But, hey, that's what Berkeley is all about! I also recommend not taking any other courses for a letter grade (i.e., if you need to take breadth courses), unless the average grade distribution is like an A- or something. Good luck!

children.subject: I think 184 is rather an extremely light workload class. Little to no work! The projects are really fun and easy to grasp!
Please no sarcasm, I really can't tell lol

I don't think either of us is being sarcastic but we probably just disagree. 184 is a project based class and in my opinion, although the projects are fun, they do take a lot of time. Its not a very conceptually difficult class though. 

The projects are in c++ and are thousands of lines long with little to no starter code. You'll probably spend a lot of time debugging. Unless you're a very strong programmer and very comfortable with c++, you will spend a lot of time on the projects imo.

184 is a project-intensive course, and I would say it's comparable to other project classes like CS 161, 162, etc.

Prof. Ren Ng taught it last semester and will be teaching it next semester; the projects do have starter code, are done in C++, and you should expect to spend a nontrivial amount of time implementing concepts learned in class and debugging your solutions. The projects ARE fun and rewarding, but whether or not the concepts are easy to grasp depend on you and any background you might have with the relevant math/graphics topics. Most students would say it's on the difficult end of the spectrum.

This is based off of my experience having taken CS 184 last semester with Prof. Ren Ng, and this doesn't reflect other versions of the course (such as with Prof. O'Brien teaching it this semester).
184 is a very heavy workload class. would not recommend it with the other two.

history.content:
Next semester I'm planning on taking CS61B, CS184, and CS70. I'm a junior transfer and have credit for CS61B already but would like to take it again here since I believe the class is significantly better. CS70 is with Sahai, CS61B with Hug, and 184 with Ren Ng. 

I've heard mixed feelings as I've consulted some people and I would appreciate additional input.
history.subject: How doable is this schedule? I would greatly appreciate advice
